title: 113_hr4662
content: The "Bureau Advisory Opinion Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. Advisory opinions are addressed in Section 2. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to include a provision for advisory opinions on prospective conduct with Federal consumer financial law. The Director will establish procedures for responding to inquiries from covered persons, consulting with regulators and obtaining public input. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to include a provision for advisory opinions on prospective conduct with Federal consumer financial law. Covered persons can make inquiries about intended conduct, but hypothetical inquiries are prohibited. They have the right to withdraw inquiries before the Director issues an opinion, which must be done within 90 days of receiving the inquiry. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 allows for advisory opinions on prospective conduct under Federal consumer financial law. The Director must issue an opinion within 90 days of receiving an inquiry, with a possible extension of up to 45 days. In any legal action under the law, there is a rebuttable presumption. In legal actions under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010, there is a rebuttable presumption that conduct in conformity with the Bureau's interpretation of Federal consumer financial law complies with the law. This presumption can be challenged with evidence, considering factors like accuracy of information submitted and alignment with the Director's opinion. The Bureau and other Federal agencies can keep documents confidential in connection with inquiries under the Consumer Financial Protection Act, exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. Assistance for small businesses is also provided by the Bureau. The Bureau will assist small businesses in preparing inquiries under this paragraph, with the definition of small business based on the Small Business Act.
